subject: Japanese Capital Spending Ex. Software (Q3) Y/Y 2.5% (Prev. 14.0%)
PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: SoftBank (9984 JT) confirmed on Friday the IPO price for mobile unit at JPY 1500/Shr
content:
JAPAN

Line (3398 JT)
- Co. extends suspension of Quick Games pending Apple store approval. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. confirmed on Friday the IPO price for mobile unit at JPY 1500/Shr. (Newswires)

Suruga Bank (8358 JT)
- Co. said that the founding family should sell stake in the firm. (Newswires)

Takeda (4502 JT)
- Co. leading family member is to hold a press conference in an effort to convince retail shareholders to oppose the Shire (SHP LN) takeover. (Newswires)

Other News
- BoJ plan to buy JPY 150-250bln 10-25yr JGBs 4 times in Dec (vs. JPY 150-250bln 5 times in Nov) and JPY 10-100bln 25-40yr JBGs 4 times in Dec (vs. JPY 10-100bln 5 times in Nov)
- US President Trump said trade deficit with Japan is coming down and hopes it will soon be balanced. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. estimated that a leak of OLED technology to Chinese rivals would cost it USD 5.8bln in sales and USD 890mln in profits over 3 years. (Newswires)

Posco (005490 KS)
- Co. said its 5 affiliates are to provide nearly USD 700mln over 5 years to help improve working conditions in their subcontractors. (Yonhap)

Other News
- South Korean President Moon said a visit by North Korean Leader Kim to Seoul is still open and possible this year, while there were separate reports that US President Trump is targeting a summit with North Korean leader early 2019. (Newswires/Nikkei)

Data Recap
- South Korean Trade Balance (USD)(Nov) 5.14B vs. Exp. 6.30B (Prev. 6.47B). (Newswires)
- South Korean Exports (Nov) Y/Y 4.5% vs. Exp. 6.6% (Prev. 22.7%)
- South Korean Imports (Nov) Y/Y 11.4% vs. Exp. 12.0% (Prev. 28.1%)

subject: Netflix (NFLX) is reportedly under investigation by UK tax authorities

US equity futures gap higher with the Emini S&P up by 1.5% and with DJIA futures higher by around 400 points following the US-China tariff ceasefire, while WTI crude is up 2.5% on the risk appetite and news Russia and Saudi agreed to extend OPEC+ deal
Virgin Australia (VAH AT) is said to have been spared from HNA (521 HK) asset sell-off for now
GrainCorp (GNC AT) reportedly received a AUD 2.4bln bid from Long-Term Asset Partners Pty
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: Reject Shop (TRS AT) shareholders rejected takeover offer from Allensford
content:
Ansell (ANN AT)
- Co. is to shut facilities in Mexico and South Korea. (Newswires)

GrainCorp (GNC AT)
- Co. reportedly may announce capital raising today. (Newswires)

Ht&e Limited. (HT1 AT)
- Co. announced it scrapped CEO position in its ARN unit. (Newswires)

Metcash (MTS AT)
- Co. H1 underlying net AUD 100mln vs. Exp. AUD 96mln. (Newswires)

Reject Shop (TRS AT)
- Co. shareholders rejected takeover offer from Allensford. (Newswires)

Santos (STO AT)
- Co. Bayu Undan infill program was said to have been finished ahead of schedule and below than planned budget. (Newswires)

TPG Telecom (TPG AT)
- Co. merged entity with Vodafone Hutchison Australia is seeking AUD 5bln in funding for proposed capital structure. (AFR)

Watpac (WTP AT)
- Co. confirmed it is in discussions for potential sale of Watpac Civil & Mining unit. (Newswires)

subject: ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Australian Building Approvals, Japanese Nikkei Manufacturing PMI and Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS: US and China agreed to a trade truce at the G20
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping announced a truce at the G20 in which the US agreed to delay the hiking tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese goods  to 25% for 90 days to allow for discussions, while China agreed to buy a "very substantial" amount of agricultural, industrial and energy products from the US. Furthermore from the G20, the draft statement agreed that the current global trading system has flaws and was in need of reform. (Newswires/BBC)

Australian AIG Manufacturing Index Nov 51.3 (Prev. 58.3). (Newswires)
Australia CBA Manufacturing PMI Nov 54.6 (prior 54.5)

New Zealand Terms of Trade QQ Q3 -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)
New Zealand Import Prices SA Q3 2.6% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 1.7%)
New Zealand Export Prices SA Q3 2.3% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.4%)
New Zealand Export Volumes SA Q3 1.8% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.1%)


UK/EU

Italian PM Conte stated they are examining several options for a budget deal with the EU in which a solution could be made within days. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Ireland at 'A+/A-1'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Portugal at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Swiss government said on Friday to adopt provisional ban on trading of Swiss shares on European stock exchanges amid row with EU over new treaty to take effect on January 1st 2019. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes Rig Count (30/Nov): Oil up 2 rigs at 887, gas down 5 rigs at 189, total rigs down 3 at 1076. (Newswires)

Russia President Putin spoke with Saudi Arabia Crown Prince in they agreed to extend the OPEC+ agreement, although haven’t decided on the precise volume of production cuts. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said on Friday that Russia plans to maintain the average October oil output level until year end, while the Russian Energy Ministry said OPEC and non-OPEC producers are comfortable with the current oil prices. (TASS)

OPEC November oil output fell by 160k BPD to 33.1mln BPD (Prev. 33.31mln BPD) after US sanctions on Iran, while OPEC members increased compliance in Nov to 120% of pledged cuts vs. revised to 110 % in October. (Newswires)

OPEC Economic Panel recommended an output cut from October levels according to reports on Friday, while it was also noted that a 1.3mln bpd cut seen as efficient to balance the market. (WSJ)
 

US

US President Trump, Canada's PM Trudeau and Mexico's Pena Nieto signed USMCA trade agreement on Friday. (Newswires)

US President Trump said on Friday that nobody knows if there will be a government shutdown. (Newswires)

US financial markets are to shut on Wednesday as a national day of mourning following the death of former US President George H.W. Bush. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

Airlines (DAL, AAL, LUV, UAL) opened higher due to a fall in crude prices, on the flipside oil producers lagged (EOG, HAL, SLB). AT&T (T) rose on it announcing increased cash flow in 2019 and a reduced debt ratio. Under Armour (UA, UAA) benefitted from an upgrade at Wells Fargo. Chipmakers NVIDIA (NVDA) and Intel (INTC) drifted higher through the day. Laboratory Corporation of America (LH) was an underperformer after announcing a soft business outlook. Marriott International (MAR) tanked after news broke of a major guest data breach. General Electric (GE) opened lower following reports it had not made adequate reserves for insurance losses. Goldman Sachs (GS) traded lower on the back of the Federal Reserve ramping up its investigation into the bank’s involvement with the Malaysian 1MDB fund. Symantec (SYMC) drifted lower after its COO resigned. SPX +0.79% at 2759, NDX +0.82% at 6949, DJI +0.75% at 25530.

The Treasury complex seems to have been detached from the broader themes (G20/trade/etc), once again putting in a lacklustre performance with a thin range, as traders refrain from making any major moves ahead of the outcome of the dinner between Trump/Xi, as well as on month-end. Fed’s Kashkari (dove, non-voter) also lent some support to the complex, though in reality, it was a rattling-off of his usual dovish views. Major curve spreads narrowed modestly by between 0.5bps to 2bps, though 10s30s were a touch wider. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 4 ticks higher at 119-17+.

subject: High beta currencies are firmer in early trade with AUD/USD up 70 pips following the US-China trade truce over the weekend at the G20
ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
